moves.1. e4: Here's a nice win from a familiar opening, using a well-known thematic sacrifice.
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6: The Najdorf Sicilian.  I continue with my revived interest in 6. Bg5.
moves.6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Qc7 8. Qf3 b5 9. Bd3 b4: I think this is probably premature.  Black needs to get his King to safety and develop his pieces.
moves.10. Nd5: !? A speculative sacrifice as I didn't have a concrete plan in mind.  But I knew this move was thematic from past studies of games by Velimirovic, Ljubojevic and Gligoric, to name a few Yugoslavians of the 70s who indulged in this line.
moves.10... exd5 11. Bxf6: White takes the opportunity to damage Black kingside pawn structure
moves.11... gxf6 12. O-O-O: Castling queenside quickly centralises White's QR and prepares for further line-opening.
moves.12... Bg7 13. exd5 Nd7: I think castling immediately would have been better.  Now Black's king is trapped in the centre.
moves.14. Rhe1+ Kd8 15. Qh5: White homes in on the weak f7 pawn but an immediate 15. Nc6+ would have been even stronger.
moves.15... Nc5: Black creates an escape square for his King but c8 would have been a better one.
